ratings.comment: Told me the second class, (in front of everyone) that I wouldn't suceed. When I came in for help she told me that she "had nothing to say to me." That being said, if you read the books and repeat her interpretations of them for the exam, you will do fine. I would much rather had opportunity to voice unique opinions, but that was prohibited.

Professor Filipowicz is very old school in her teaching. Although she requires constant class participation, she basically lectures at the class for 75 min. She is a very well educated woman with a lot of knowledge, but in assignments it's very much so "her way or the highway." The tests are pure regurgitation but essays are pretty tough.

She tells you exactly what to take away from each reading, so if you can reproduce her points from class on an exam you will get nothing less than an A+ in this course. She wants you to agree with her interpretation of readings, not make your own. Very nice lady who takes Polish literature seriously. I would recommend this class with Filipowicz.
Awful, avoid at all costs. Power lecture was awful and she rambles. Not clear with material and did not stay on topic.

I would have been cool with the strict requirements if she were a helpful or effective professor. every single one of her lectures was an hour of rambling and 15 minutes of actual useful info. there's 3 "quizzes" worth 36% of your grade, a final paper and 2 midterms. she's not constructive and very condescending. i would avoid this class.

I didn't mind her old school methods or mandatory attendance or even her rambling so much as I minded how she treated me. She made me feel stupid when I asked questions and all but told me I would not succeed in the class. I wish I had researched her more before taking the class; had I done so, I never would've taken it to begin with.

Most boring class I have ever taken. She teaches with a very old school style: everything in hard copy, no eating, no phones, no laptops, and attendance is taken every class. Also assigns a ridiculous amount of reading for quizzes/tests. (For the last test we had to read 4 entire books and a play)

Professor Filipowicz teaches in an old school style. No laptops, no eating, and she takes attendance every class. While this requires some getting used to, the class is pretty interesting. Exams consist of two essays, and the questions are given to you in advance. If you do the readings and participate in her discussions, the class should be easy.
She was terrible. She would not help you and her instructions for papers were unclear. Her lectures are redundant and rambling. I would not ever advise taking one of her classes.

She was a pretty horrible teacher, probably one of the worst I've ever had. She rambled throughout the entire class and did not offer any help whatsoever. If you went in for advice, she rambled on about things completely off topic. I would never advise taking her. A lot of other students I know dropped the Polish major because of her.

A really interesting class. Readings are abundant, but the work isn't really that bad. 3 papers, 2 writing exams, and a final paper. She rambles in lecture for almost half the class, but it makes it go by quicker. Pretty easy grader, although she can demand very specific responses at times. Overall, good class. Take it if you need literature credit
